The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: Growing up in a large city, I've come to appreciate the eclectic mix of cultures and lifestyles that make up my neighborhood. Commercial and residential areas blend seamlessly together, with a diverse array of businesses scattered throughout. You can find everything from office buildings to unique stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues. The dining options are endless, and shopping is a breeze, with everything from big-name brands to small, independent boutiques on offer. Some stores can be found in sprawling malls, while others line the streets, often within walking distance of quieter neighborhoods. The area is also dotted with parks, which are frequented by families with young children. In terms of community diversity, my neighborhood is a melting pot, with a notable LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a significant population of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union, all coexisting in a small, vibrant area. As you venture further into the city, you'll find even more diverse neighborhoods, such as Korea town, China town, and Little Armenia, each with its own unique character. However, getting from one place to another can be a challenge, as the city's massive size and notorious traffic jams make walking a rare occurrence. In fact, driving just 10 miles can take hours, especially during rush hour. While some areas are within walking distance, the city's huge size means that most people rely on cars to get around. The result is some of the world's worst traffic and a never-ending search for parking spots. Interestingly, despite the chaos, the city has seen a surge in construction, with new apartment buildings sprouting up left and right. While this has made the city a popular destination for some, many residents are worried about the added pressure on the roads and the loss of the area's character. One of the things that's striking about my neighborhood is the variety of housing options available. Not everyone lives in a high-rise apartment building, and there's a range of single-family homes, smaller apartment buildings, and condominiums to choose from. Even within my immediate neighborhood, you can find a mix of housing styles, from cozy single-family homes to duplexes. The neighborhood is also home to people of all ages, and I must admit that I don't know most of my neighbors. While it's not a tight-knit community like it was when I was a child, playing with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood, I have fond memories of those carefree days.

My neighborhood is a true reflection of the American experience, with its mix of single-family homes, some of which have been divided into two, yet still connected. My house features a small front yard and a driveway to the left, reminiscent of a bygone era when suburban living was the epitome of the American dream. This dream, once seemingly all-encompassing, now appears to be slowly slipping away, yet my neighborhood, along with many others, still lingers, beckoning to passersby and visitors that the dream remains, even if tenuously held onto. The residents, while less optimistic than in the past, continue to cling to this ideal, evident in the abandoned lawns and the numerous cars parked in driveways. Children still play freely, oblivious to the world beyond their front porch. The local public school, a 90-year-old institution, stands as a symbol of hope for the youth and nostalgia for the older residents. The churches, although dwindling in number, remain empty, while the basketball courts continue to thrive. Despite the unique architecture of each home, they all exude a sense of familiarity. A local supermarket, "Super A," owned by a Yemeni family, stands out as a cultural anomaly in a predominantly African American community. The streets are wide, and football is the sport of choice, with cars yielding to the children as they play. Many residents have lived here for generations, and their stories of a bygone era, where everyone knew each other, are a testament to the neighborhood's rich history. A former karate school now operates as a pharmacy, a nod to the changing times. A small, old-fashioned movie theater, showing classic films at a discounted price, may not appeal to the youth, but it remains a beloved institution for the older residents, who cherish its nostalgic charm. A nearby expressway, which passes through the adjacent town, has been a point of contention, with the youth supporting its construction and the elderly opposing it, fearing it would ruin the neighborhood's character. The community is currently deciding on a new high school mascot, with a proposal for a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin being a peculiar yet intriguing choice, one that might aptly represent the neighborhood's unique character.

At first glance, it might seem like a typical residential area, tucked behind a strip mall and not exactly a place people would want to live. However, if you venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk past the hotels that are only occupied seasonally, you'll stumble upon a thriving community. This hidden neighborhood is situated next to several apartment complexes, carefully arranged like a series of Russian nesting dolls that have been thoughtfully placed side by side down the road. 

While the first apartment complex has garnered some negative attention, a closer look reveals that the surrounding areas are a world apart from the one that's often perceived. The community college's satellite campus stands quietly across the street, where students slowly start their day with a cup of coffee, yawning at 7 am. The iron gates creak open as they arrive, occasionally causing commuters to slam on their brakes and grumble about the traffic congestion on busy days.

The road intersects with another residential street, lined with a park and a rehabilitation center for individuals recovering from unfortunate accidents. The center boasts charming porch furniture and a meandering ceiling fan that stirs the hot summer air. Children playfully run through the park's grass, while bees lazily flit around the nearby flowers. Retirees walk their dogs on the path, scrutinizing the teenagers on skateboards and exchanging polite smiles with the girls gossiping by the playground equipment. A sushi restaurant in the adjacent strip mall offers affordable food but remains relatively quiet, nestled beside a swimming supply store and a nail salon in between.

You can simultaneously fill your pool, get a manicure, and enjoy a hibachi meal at this strip mall hub. There's also a do-it-yourself frozen yogurt shop nearby, often frequented by teenagers who pair their frozen treats with tricks on their skateboards and vaping. This neighborhood is a quintessential slice of Americana, a piece of history frozen in time in the sleepy south, where the pace of life remains unchanged.

As we drove past the seemingly endless cornfields that stretched across the horizon, my companion looked puzzled. "Where is everything?" she asked, unfamiliar with the vast openness of the landscape. I chuckled knowingly, anticipating her reaction. Born and raised in a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her doorstep, she was accustomed to a more urban environment. I shared with her stories of growing up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she began to grasp where I came from.

As we continued down the winding two-lane road, we passed a quarry filled with water, followed by a small development where I reside. The neighborhood is characterized by its brick and stucco homes, each boasting at least half an acre of land for the residents to tend to with pride. During the spring, the streets are adorned with vibrant flowers and the changing colors of the Midwestern trees, painting a picture of natural beauty. The driveways are lined with sleek Mercedes-Benz luxury cars, polished to perfection after a refreshing car wash. As we approached my house, a warm smile from my Korean neighbor greeted us. He spends his days mowing his lawn and singing along to the hum of his John Deere Zero Turn mower, a daily ritual that brings joy to the entire neighborhood.

As we pulled up to my home, the sounds of geese and our Terrier's playful barks filled the air. The nearby stream, which feeds into the quarry, provided a soothing melody, accompanied by the occasional bullfrog chirp and the distant "moo" from the nearby farms. A small wooden bridge spanned the stream, leading to a serene oasis overgrown with wildflowers, herbs, and naturally occurring trees. This secret haven was where I spent most of my childhood, creating tree forts, chasing imaginary animals, and forming lifelong friendships with the neighborhood kids. The harsh winters in my small town may have been brutal, but they were also breathtakingly beautiful. The once-vibrant flowers and trees stood bare and skeletal, their branches etched against the sky. Snowfall transformed the yard into a winter wonderland, complete with snow angels and snowmen crafted by my little sister. Our frequent sibling squabbles were temporarily forgotten in the midst of our snowy adventures, as we built elaborate forts and engaged in epic snowball battles. In our own little world, we were carefree children, lost in the magic of childhood.

To truly understand the essence of Portland, Oregon, one must grasp the concept of 'weird'. An unofficial town slogan, 'Keep Portland Weird', proudly plastered on a building that serves as a multifaceted establishment - pizza joint, bar, music venue, and more - encapsulates the city's peculiar charm. For some, this slogan is a nostalgic call to remember the Portland of the 1990s and early 2000s, when it was less known and less expensive, fostering a haven for creative and unique subcultures. Others see it as an invitation - come to Portland, where individuality is celebrated, and being different is a compliment. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the proliferation of condominiums to accommodate them, Portland's eccentricity remains. It means embracing things that are generally not accepted, but not necessarily always tolerant. Like the rest of the country, Portlanders purchase most of their goods from overseas, and we have our share of modern conveniences and the problems that come with them. The city is a melting pot of weirdness, with yoga enthusiasts, hipsters, and business professionals coexisting alongside each other. Perhaps what makes Portland truly weird is our propensity to take ourselves less seriously. In my neighborhood, like many others, residents showcase their creativity through colorful houses, home gardens bursting with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and the ubiquitous free boxes that line the streets in the summer. These free boxes, usually made of cardboard, may contain anything - clothes, books, or even the occasional surprise. The magic of stumbling upon a treasure in a Southeast Portland neighborhood is quintessential Portland. However, not everyone shares this perspective. Some residents I live among would never consider rummaging through a free box, opting instead for more...unconventional activities like goat yoga or attending a Timbers match. Portland is a city where people pursue their passions, whether it's a love for soccer, yoga, or simply a good time at the bar. Like many cities, Portland struggles with issues like substance abuse, which often stem from deeper mental health concerns, and a homelessness problem that seems to defy solutions. Our social services, while better than in many parts of the country, are insufficient. The non-homeless population is torn between empathy and disdain, a sentiment shared by many cities. In this regard, Portland is not so weird after all.

Permanently standing tall, the mountains have been a constant presence in the north, watching over the sun's daily journey from dawn to dusk. No matter how consumed by work and life's demands I become, they remain steadfast, unyielding to life's turmoil. It's during times of stress and turmoil that they rise to prominence, beckoning me to pause and find solace. I recall my arrival here as an undergraduate, and it was the mountains in the north of campus that first captured my heart. While the university itself boasts impressive sights in its architecture, ponds, and trees, the mountains hold a special place in my affections. The town has its own unique charm, with numerous cafes serving as havens for all-night study sessions fueled by coffee. A short walk or bus ride leads to the downtown area, where the faded, colorful bricks of restaurants and office buildings transport me to a bygone era. The dichotomy of these two atmospheres, existing in such close proximity, imbues the town with an air of wonder, inviting exploration. This dynamic setting has allowed me to create many cherished memories, each tied to a particular part of the town. Whether it's strolling past the old swings in the park with friends after a late-night study session or rushing through the bustling downtown to catch a movie at the university-provided theater, this town has been a canvas for both joyful and poignant experiences. The ponds, in particular, have become a sanctuary for reflection and heart-to-hearts during late-night existential crises. As I sat amidst the peaceful surroundings, watching the turtles, ducks, and insects go about their lives, I couldn't help but ponder my own life's purpose. I wandered past the pond, through the park, and the quiet suburban houses, until I reached the main street. It was then that the sun broke through the horizon, casting its warm rays upon the palm trees, and as I gazed up at the sunrise, I felt an inexplicable sense of direction. Sure enough, they were there, just as they had always been: the majestic mountains, towering above the hazy sky, silently urging me forward with a sense of perseverance.

Visitors to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, won't have trouble finding the neighborhood due to its excellent public transportation options, which are in high demand throughout New York City. The area itself is urban, giving visitors a quintessential New York City experience. You'll notice an abundance of Asian-owned stores, a result of the significant influx of Asian residents over the past two decades. Every few blocks, you'll find an Asian market, laundromat, or other business catering to the community's needs. These stores are popular among locals for their high-quality products, affordable prices, and convenient locations. In fact, just a short walk from here, there are no fewer than four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute radius, making grocery shopping a breeze. Although Bensonhurst is predominantly Asian, it's not exclusively so, with a diverse mix of immigrants and their American-born children.

The local economy is largely driven by Asian-owned businesses, along with a renovated park featuring multiple basketball courts, a soccer or baseball field, handball courts, a playground, and a water fountain. As in other parts of New York City, the park is a melting pot of cultures, where people of all backgrounds can coexist and enjoy the facilities. Unlike other areas, Bensonhurst has a low number of corporate buildings, with most residents living in co-op apartments or condominiums, or in two-family houses.

While the neighborhood is generally safe, some caution is advised, especially at night, as there have been incidents of bullying, theft, and rowdiness. I've personally experienced bullying in the past, although this was many years ago. More recently, there have been reports of package theft. It's also worth noting that dog owners in the area often fail to pick up after their pets, leaving droppings on sidewalks and streets, which can be a nuisance.

The neighborhood where I live is quite hilly, with many areas descending sharply downhill. My house is situated at the top of the steepest slope in the community, earning it a nickname: the "workout hill." Due to the lack of sidewalks, residents often walk on the road, which can be hazardous, especially during inclement weather when the road becomes pitted and uneven. On top of that, the telephone and electric wires stretching along the street appear worn and frayed, as frequent storms and branch damage necessitate constant repairs. The landscape is dotted with tall evergreen trees, yet many residents disdain them, cutting them down to improve their views of the ocean. As a result, houses are built high up on the hill, with expansive glass-fronted second stories that offer unobstructed views of the bay. During sunset, the water takes on a beautiful, golden hue, and the sky transforms into a kaleidoscope of orange shades. However, the area is often shrouded in clouds, resulting in a hazy atmosphere and limited sunlight. Moss thrives in this damp environment, covering cars, roofs, and railings with a thick, green carpet. I once left my car parked for a month, only to find it covered in moss when I returned. It took hours to remove the unwanted growth. In contrast to the lively atmosphere of other neighborhoods, my area is relatively quiet, with few children and a school located a short distance away. The majority of residents are older, many of whom are retired. Instead of kids, families have dogs, which are a common sight lounging in yards or racing down the street. If you leave a door or window open, you risk inviting them into your home. I've had to shoo one out of my living room before. Rabbits also roam freely, causing problems for gardeners as they dig up plant roots and burrow into lawns. My cats, however, enjoy hunting them, and have largely eradicated the rabbit population from our neighborhood. Birds, including sparrows, hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle, can be spotted in the area. The neighborhood crows often chase the larger birds away. For shopping and dining, residents must head downhill to the waterfront, where a few restaurants serve fresh seafood. The beach itself is small, but the rocky shoreline is a popular spot for skipping rocks into the water. The bay is relatively narrow, making it easy to spot the opposite shoreline, even on cloudy days.

I live in a typical suburban area of a small southern town in Tennessee, situated near the intersection of two state highways. While this brings a moderate amount of traffic to the street, the neighborhood remains relatively quiet overall. The area experiences a low turnover in residents, allowing me to be familiar with most of my neighbors. People generally spend their time tending to their yards and daily chores. During winter, we enjoy sledding down a nearby hill on our side street. Our house is located at the front corner of the street, providing us with a front-row view of all the activity and a chance to note any unfamiliar vehicles. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs, while kids spend their time playing on their bikes. As we work from home, we often find ourselves spending a lot of time at home. My wife and I reside here with our two daughters, aged 11 and 14. As a result, our neighbors are also accustomed to seeing us come and go. We like to get outside and play, even on rainy days, and occasionally fire up the barbecue on our back deck, filling the air with the pleasant aroma of grilled food. The constant sound of lawn mowers during the warmer months is a common occurrence, as many neighbors maintain their lawns. The neighborhood's original wooded landscape still has many trees, providing ample shade, although it also results in a significant amount of leaf cleanup each autumn. We enjoy the smell of burning leaves, which signals the start of the fall season. Lately, the mild winters have made the transition from fall to winter seem less distinct. Our garage is located at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door, except when someone knocks. I often find myself working on my truck or other projects in the garage, with the open doors allowing me to stay connected to the neighborhood. On holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, the neighborhood is usually quiet, with some families hosting out-of-town visitors, resulting in a higher number of parked cars. In general, I am content with my living arrangement, and if it weren't for the through traffic, it would be an ideal place to reside.

I reside in a neighborhood situated in the heart of the high desert, an area characterized by expanses of dirt and sand as far as the eye can see. Unless one has lived here personally, it's difficult to grasp the monotony of gazing at endless brown vistas and appreciating the rare sight of a well-manicured lawn. When I first moved to this area in the 1990s, homes were scattered far apart, but over the years, the landscape has undergone significant changes, with new developments sprouting up and transforming the once-sparsely populated area into a more urban landscape. Despite this transformation, the community remains a mix of good and not-so-good aspects, just like any city. The neighborhood I call home boasts a friendly atmosphere, with many long-time residents who have created a sense of warmth and camaraderie. The local stores are largely chain establishments, offering a familiar array of options like discount groceries and department stores. However, for those seeking specialty items or upscale shopping, a trip out of town is often necessary. The local job market is largely driven by the construction industry, which is a natural consequence of the city's relatively undeveloped state and the abundance of open spaces waiting to be built upon. This trend has both benefits and drawbacks, as it contributes to the area's growth and development but also poses concerns about overurbanization. As someone who works in construction, installing drywall and T-bar ceilings, I have a unique perspective on this dynamic. What I cherish most about my home is the unique wildlife that inhabits this area. Many people are drawn to the high desert for its stark beauty and challenging ecosystems, which support a diverse array of flora and fauna. As a resident, it's essential to be aware of and respect the non-human inhabitants of this environment to coexist peacefully. My family and I have grown accustomed to the wildlife, and my children are particularly fascinated by the lizards and insects that call this place home. If you're planning a visit to our area, Victorville has a range of attractions to offer. Families can experience the desert's unique charm, and the annual San Bernardino County Fair is an excellent event to coincide with your visit. Visitors can also explore the nearby Wrightwood, known for its snow-capped mountains, and take advantage of winter sports opportunities. For those interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is a must-visit destination, featuring a collection of geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the area's development and growth.

When I describe my neighborhood, my response is likely to stand out from the crowd. Unlike many others who define their neighborhoods in terms of a specific location, I consider the college campus where I reside as my neighborhood, with my dormitory and its residents being my community. While this perspective might seem unusual, it shares some commonalities with the traditional concept of a neighborhood. Just like any ordinary neighborhood, my college campus has its own set of characteristics, including houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by examining the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before delving into the specifics, it's essential to note the different types of housing available in my area. There are three primary types: apartments, houses, and dormitory-style buildings.

Firstly, the apartments typically accommodate 2-4 individuals per room, with 4-6 rooms on each floor. This results in around 20-40 people residing in each building, which can span two floors. Second, there are the houses available for rent, usually 2-4 bedroom setups, often occupied by alumni. However, these are relatively scarce, as they are not as efficient as other housing options. Lastly, the dorm rooms are the most common type, housing hundreds of students, with each room typically shared by two individuals, although there are some exceptions.

Moving on to the people, my school prides itself on its diversity, which is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. The professional staff reside in the houses, while newer students stay in dorms and older students in apartments. It's challenging to do justice to the people in my neighborhood, so let's proceed to discuss the stores and parks. Given that my school is a self-contained community, it has a wide range of stores, including dining options, clothing stores, and grocery stores, ensuring that everything one needs can be found within the neighborhood's boundaries. The park in my neighborhood serves as a playground for the diverse community, with the residents working together to maintain its cleanliness and safety.

It's been a decade since I've called this neighborhood home, and I've learned a thing or two about it during that time. When I first moved here from Riverdale to Stockbridge, I have to admit I was heartbroken. I missed my old home and loved ones, and it took me a while to adjust to the change. However, my parents made the move with the best intentions – they wanted a better life for my sister and me, with improved housing, a better high school, and a more welcoming environment. Over the years, I've grown accustomed to my new surroundings and made some wonderful friends, as well as a few acquaintances I'd rather forget. While I never really got to know many of my neighbors, there are a few who stand out, like Mr. Glen and his family, who live right next door. They've become like family to me, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. I still remember the joy of attending Mr. Glen's wedding and celebrating with him and his loved ones. It's a memory I cherish, and I hope to create similar experiences in the future when I build my own life and provide for my future partner. One particular moment from that special day still brings a smile to my face – when Mr. Glen's wife, Ms. Veda, removed a decorative strap from her leg and playfully threw it, and I managed to catch it (unfortunately, I wasn't lucky enough to catch the bouquet!). We danced the night away, and I had a great time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. Although I haven't seen her in a while, I wish her all the best. The neighborhood itself is a labyrinth, but with the help of a GPS, I've started to explore it more thoroughly. I've spent some quality time with friends Kason and Curtis, and we've had our fair share of fun playing video games and enjoying life to the fullest. I also appreciate the park nearby, which offers a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of everyday life. It's a place where I can clear my mind and recharge my batteries. I often bring some sticks from Home Depot and practice my balance, and I also enjoy taking my bokken wooden sword for a spin. Although I haven't played tennis or basketball in a while, I'm glad to have the facilities available in case I ever feel like dusting off my old skills. My dad taught me and my best friend the art of tennis with Mr. Graves, and those were some wonderful memories. Looking back, I've had my fair share of fun experiences in this neighborhood, and I'm excited to see what the future holds.

My neighborhood is adjacent to the college I attend, which is a significant advantage in my eyes. The area is primarily characterized by apartment buildings, a few restaurants, and bars that are affordable and enjoyable to visit. One of these bars has recently undergone a name change and has become pricier, but the service and drinks are still decent. The majority of residents are either college students or individuals with lower incomes, due to the relatively affordable apartment prices. There's a substantial number of children in the area, thanks to the nearby elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I've yet to get to know my neighbors, but that's largely because they often engage in activities that I'm not interested in, such as smoking weed. In response, my building management installed an air freshener unit in front of their door, which my boyfriend and I found amusing, albeit slightly insulting. The buildings surrounding me have an older appearance, but some may have undergone renovations. In a nearby street, there are newer apartments, but I'm not a fan of them because I'm aware of the subpar construction and the high rent prices. It seems like the management is taking advantage of the fact that the apartments are near campus. There's a budget-friendly eatery about a five-minute walk from my apartment that serves meals on paper plates and mostly cooks food in a microwave. Across the street is a gas station, which I've heard has poor working conditions. However, the area has undergone some improvements thanks to municipal funding, including the repaving of the road and the addition of new sidewalks, grass, and landscaping. My apartment building is surrounded by trees, which has resulted in a few stumps after some were cut down. In contrast, the street behind my complex has fewer trees and is lined with another set of apartments. The area I live on, 42nd street, has its advantages, but the street behind it, 43rd street, is less desirable due to its poorly maintained sidewalks and run-down buildings. Despite the presence of some trees, the street may be trying to hide its true appearance. A significant portion of the crime in my area has occurred at an apartment complex on 43rd street, but it's not the only source of the problem – there are other apartments across the street with a high crime rate and a transient population. Nevertheless, I'm pleased with my current living situation, as I can afford it and have access to various amenities, including the university within walking distance and convenient bus stops to get to the store and downtown areas.

My neighborhood is comprised of duplexes situated in a cul-de-sac, with an intermittent arrangement that gives the illusion of individual homes. Each is painted a uniform yellow, paired with white porches and green metal roofs, setting it apart from the cookie-cutter architecture that dominates the surrounding landscape. While many residents are friendly and acquainted with one another, not everyone is close. However, on certain evenings, we gather at the end of a driveway, engaging in casual conversations as our children play outside, using sidewalk chalk, flying kites, or watching the neighborhood children. This tranquil environment stands out amidst the chaos of modern life, where technology seems to reign supreme. It's as if we've stepped back in time, surrounded by lush fields, towering trees, and serene blue skies with puffy white clouds. However, our peaceful existence has been disrupted this season by the threat of tornadoes. For the first time, we've experienced the ominous sound of tornado sirens, prompting us to seek shelter. I found myself huddled in my bathtub, clutching my small dog and a few essential items, while my bigger dog remained in the living room, visibly distressed by the unusual circumstances. The only sounds were the hail pounding against the ground. Following the storm, the temperature rapidly dropped, and the road was left steaming from the dramatic change. The hail melted instantly upon hitting the scorching pavement. As the skies cleared, the sun broke through, and a double rainbow materialized. I hastily grabbed my camera and snapped photographs to share with my friends and family on social media, who were all equally awestruck. The neighborhood remained quiet for a while longer, until residents began to trickle back home after the storm had passed. As the evening wore on, it was business as usual, with mothers and children resuming their evening routines, while dinner cooked inside. Our neighborhood has a unique charm, especially for someone like me who recently relocated from New Hampshire to North Carolina. I've grown to appreciate the distinct southern accent and hospitality that defines our community. Each of the two-bedroom apartments, including mine, has its own unique interior, despite their uniform exterior appearance. Some apartments are surprisingly small, making it difficult to fathom the disparity in living spaces. I thoroughly enjoy strolling through the adjacent field, making my way to the pond, which, although not suitable for swimming, offers a serene escape. I've spotted deer roaming freely, and on mornings, the melodic song of a bullfrog fills the air. This is a hidden gem of a neighborhood, nestled just forty minutes outside the bustling city of Charlotte. The day begins with the soothing sound of roosters crowing from the nearby farms, creating a sense of a small, close-knit village. We're even treated to the evening serenade of a donkey's braying from a nearby farm, serving as a reminder of the community's rustic charm. I feel fortunate to have discovered this enchanting neighborhood.

I moved to my current neighborhood right before starting eighth grade, and it took some time to adjust and make friends. Luckily, I quickly formed close bonds with two people who lived nearby - one two houses down from me and the other on my street. Although we've lost touch with them over time, the memories of our time together remain. The people who were here when I first moved in are still mostly living here, giving my neighborhood a sense of continuity. Our neighborhood is a quintessential American suburban community, characterized by its many two-story houses. On weekends and warm days, the sounds of children playing outside fill the air. While it's generally quiet throughout the week, I've never experienced any issues with my neighbors, who respect people's personal space unless they need help. In fact, I've ordered multiple packages online without worrying about them going missing from my porch. This sense of trust extends to our diverse neighborhood, where you're unlikely to find any trouble unless you need assistance. A nearby park has become a source of nostalgia for me, where I spent countless hours playing basketball, football, and baseball with my neighbors as a kid. While it also holds the memory of my worst football-related injury - a painful elbow to the nose - the good times far outweigh the bad. Nowadays, I visit the park to spend time with my younger cousin's kids, who still enjoy the simple joys of playground equipment. The park's nostalgic charm remains strong, evoking happy memories of my childhood. Our neighborhood is a melting pot of cultures, with an array of cuisines available within a one-mile radius. You can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants, as well as fast food chains. However, with the rise of food delivery apps like GrubHub and DoorDash, many residents prefer to have their meals delivered. The local stores are well-stocked and diverse, with multiple dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store. There's even an Indian-owned store for those who want to cook homemade Indian food or buy pre-made meals. Overall, I'm grateful for my neighborhood, especially when I see the challenges others face with their neighbors on social media and in the news.

Johnston is a charming, unassuming town in South Carolina that makes a significant impact on the state's agricultural sector. The town proudly bills itself as the Peach Capital of the World, a claim reflected on the town's welcoming sign. Predominantly consisting of farmland, the area is dotted with peach trees and cattle farms, while the houses are spread out, with most being two-story homes featuring metal or gray shingle roofs to combat the scorching summer heat. These homes are often situated away from the road, allowing the front fields to be used for livestock or crops. In the town's central area, a single stoplight controls traffic at a four-way intersection, where visitors can find the only stores within the town. The options for fast food are limited to Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, and Gary's, a small burger chain. A former pizzeria has closed down, but residents can still access basic essentials at Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small, family-owned pharmacy known for selling Cherry Coca-Cola. Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, is the local grocery store, but many residents prefer to shop at a nearby Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville to buy their groceries. The town's most popular destination is Dollar General, which offers a wide array of everyday items and is often bustling from opening to closing time. Possibilities Furniture & More, a small furniture store run by a well-respected member of the community, also employs two movers to deliver purchased items. The store is attached to Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet groomer offering various services like daycare, boarding, and grooming. The town's healthcare services are provided by two small but well-equipped practices: a doctor's office and a veterinary clinic, both located outside the main area. Johnston Elementary School is the town's only elementary school, and students typically transfer to middle and high school in the adjacent town after completing the fifth grade. While there are no parks in the town, a new 2.5-acre recreational area is currently under development to provide families with more leisure options and attract new residents. Despite its limited amenities – including no movie theaters, bowling alleys, or large variety of restaurants – Johnston remains a pleasant town that could easily be overlooked if one didn't take a closer look.

The first time I came across my neighborhood, it was in a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a bit surprising, considering almost every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard about that story, nor had any of my friends. It's possible that's because of the struggles we face. I know a few friends who cry themselves to sleep at night due to financial struggles. Despite the high costs, we've learned to live frugally over the years, finding ways to appreciate the simple things – like the smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. As you grow older, you become accustomed to the state of things, and you may even start smoking or adopt other habits. However, the flea market always finds a way to assert itself. The smell of adulthood is often dusty magazines stacked on an old piano, and it can linger long after you wash the leather. In my neighborhood, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start on one end, you can visit two charity thrift stores, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. The area is bustling with activity, especially in the morning when cars and people fill the streets. But inside the thrift stores, it's peaceful – a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, the area becomes even more crowded, with more cars and people flooding the streets. It's a rapidly developing city, with one of the largest online e-commerce empires headquartered here, showcasing its growing pains. It reminds me of New York, where everyone is focused on their own goals, and people tend to leave you alone if you prefer to be quiet and independent. It's a far cry from the South, where showing a little concern for others is seen as caring. You can maintain your shell and keep to yourself as long as you'd like, and the city will continue to thrive around you. The area is lively, with the pianist next door and the amateur vocalists upstairs providing a constant source of entertainment. In a way, we've created a community of friends, where we come together for celebrations, condolences, and mutual support. I feel fortunate to live here, surrounded by neighbors I like and who treat me well. We look out for one another, exchanging food and mail, and I appreciate their presence in my life just as much as they do mine. Despite the sprawling, modernist surroundings, it's the kindness of my neighbors that makes me feel like I haven't completely given up on life.

The suburban community in which I reside is a quintessential example of a cookie-cutter neighborhood. Upon entering my neighborhood, it's evident that the homeowner's association plays a significant role in maintaining the area's uniform appearance. Every home is well-maintained, and the streets are lined with single-family houses that share a striking similarity in design. The front yards are meticulously landscaped, with neat patches of grass, decorative pebbles, and short driveways. Some houses have two-car garages, while others are slightly taller with two stories. 

The neighborhood's infrastructure is also noteworthy, with newly paved concrete roads and a lack of potholes, making it a comfortable place to drive through. While the houses vary in height, the streets are well-maintained, and the absence of individual mailboxes in front of each home is instead replaced by a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street, accessible with a key. The neighborhood's HOA has also seen fit to provide two larger lockers for packages. 

Geographically, my neighborhood is situated on the outskirts of the nearby city, blending elements of both rural and suburban landscapes. This unique blend offers ample space for various community amenities, including well-maintained, gated pools and walking trails perfect for exercising or taking a leisurely stroll. The neighborhood is large enough to allow for a good workout by simply running around it. The community consists primarily of retirees, but also has a smaller population of middle-aged and young professionals. 

The nearby city, while large in terms of population, has a surprisingly small-town feel. Residents have access to a wide range of amenities, including a single mall that meets the community's shopping needs. While it's not a large mall, it provides an assortment of stores, from high-end grocery stores offering organic options to bargain outlets with minimal staff. The drive time to access these amenities is relatively short, around 15 minutes, and the variety of stores available is impressive. Overall, my neighborhood offers a safe, well-maintained, and familiar environment, complete with desirable community features and easy access to a range of shopping options.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just beyond the suburbs of a major city. The neighborhood where I live, located on the east side, is characterized as being economically disadvantaged. Property values in this area are relatively low, with the majority of homes being rented or owned by low-income residents. However, the neighborhood's appearance is not unappealing, and it's a place where people are generally friendly and willing to greet each other with a smile. While crime rates are slightly higher in this area compared to other parts of the town, they remain relatively low. There have been a few instances of violent crimes within a short distance from my home over the past decade, including a few shootings and one homicide. A tragic incident occurred when our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar. Fortunately, my family has not been directly affected by crime, although we have occasionally had items go missing from our porch when we forget to bring them inside. Our town has been significantly impacted by the nationwide opioid epidemic, which has led to numerous losses due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are various resources available in my town to combat this issue, including multiple addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those struggling with addiction. Despite the challenges, this town boasts several positive attributes. The local elementary school has an exceptional staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff, who create a welcoming atmosphere. My son, who has special needs, has not experienced any bullying, and he genuinely enjoys attending school. The school's Parent-Teacher Organization actively organizes events to foster family involvement and educational progress. Due to the high poverty rate in our town, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring that no child goes hungry. No family is ever made to feel inferior due to financial constraints, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are reasonably affordable. The City Council and municipal staff have made significant improvements to the town's appearance, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have focused on the town's center and west side, where shopping areas and major traffic routes are located. The east side, where I reside, has been somewhat neglected, which has raised concerns among my neighbors. Overall, I find living in this town to be a pleasant experience. Residents are generally friendly, the schools are excellent, there are sufficient shopping options to meet our needs, and although our home's value may be low, it is comfortable and sufficient for our family. We have called this town home for over 16 years, and it is difficult to imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is a vibrant cultural hub nestled at the top of a hill, surrounded by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a 7-story apartment building directly across from the old theater, with a block away being a trendy arcade bar that attracts a diverse crowd on warm summer evenings. It's not uncommon to spot a line of people waiting to get in, especially during weekends in June and July. Just a few blocks away lies the local city park, which is surprisingly spacious given its location. The park's perimeter is bounded by concrete, with stairs embedded in the wall. As the winter months bring frigid temperatures, homeless individuals set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the wide steps. While snowfall is rare, the frequent torrential downpours in mid-winter make it challenging to stay warm. By clustering their tents in the city center, rather than in a distant area, they can maintain a relative sense of warmth. Moreover, they are within walking or transit distance to the only family center in the area, where they can access bathing and shower facilities. What I cherish about my city, though, is not the historic architecture or the picturesque views – the tall buildings, the varied architectural styles, or the landscape that rolls down towards the ocean. What I love is the community itself. Hilltop's history as a neighborhood plagued by gang violence is still palpable, even decades after the fact. Stories of federal officials and the DEA's attempts to clean up the streets continue to be shared among the residents. These stories are passed down through generations, even to newcomers like myself. Despite its rough reputation, the community strives to keep the area clean and well-maintained. The people care deeply about their city and their block. There's a lingering warning that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill at night. I believe this warning is a reminder of the past, tinged with the bitter taste of social conditioning. It's possible that I'm able to navigate the neighborhood with relative ease because I'm light-skinned enough to pass, or perhaps Hilltop has accepted me as one of their own, someone who's acutely aware of the persistent reminders that plague our nation. These reminders of racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions based on ignorance and fear are a stark contrast to the notion of a cultural melting pot Utopia. What I do know is that no matter where life takes me, the Hilltop will always be home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have shown me kindness and generosity, often in ways that defy expectation. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open late to let me charge my phone on a rainy night, and where strangers have stopped to offer me a jacket, tell me I'm beautiful, and remind me of my worth.

I reside in a rural area of small-town Michigan, where the landscape shifts from vast farmland to quaint tourist towns. The absence of large city malls, big-box stores like Walmart and Target, and chain restaurants like Applebee's, means that residents often need to drive to access various amenities. Surprisingly, I live in one of the world's most breathtaking locations, surrounded by two majestic lakes, Lake Michigan to the east and Lake Charlevoix to the west. The scenic views and waterfront properties make this area an attractive place to call home. My neighborhood reflects the quintessential charm of small-town America. The houses are not cookie-cutter developments, but rather unique, older homes that have been lovingly maintained or renovated over the years. Many of these homes feature basements, which are often visible from the street, and some have been updated with modern touches. Aluminum siding is a common feature in many of the homes, and the neighborhood's diverse color palette adds to its character. Each house has a yard, with some featuring trampolines, playsets, gardens, and fences for pets. The neighborhood exudes a sense of traditional, hardworking America, where families are raised and community bonds are strong. On any given day, you can see children playing in the streets, neighbors walking their dogs, biking, or rollerblading. The sense of camaraderie is palpable, with residents often greeting one another with a wave or a friendly smile. The lawns are well-maintained, with green grass and trim landscaping adding to the neighborhood's appeal. While the homes may not be showpieces, they represent a sense of community and normalcy that many people aspire to. The presence of local amenities, such as the county sheriff's department and jail, health department, and recycling center, further solidifies the area's small-town feel. The nearby baseball and softball fields, airport, and local ice cream shop add to the charm of this rural Michigan community. My children can easily bike to the nearby park, which is just a few blocks away, making this a wonderful place to raise a family. The peaceful atmosphere, sense of security, and strong community ties make this small town an exceptional place to call home.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road.
